title: Waste packaging reprocessor accreditation (England, Wales and Scotland)

details.description: You can apply for the waste packaging reprocessor registration if you recover, recycle or exporting packaging waste for recovery overseas
details.licence_short_description: Register for waste packaging reprocessor accreditation if you recover, recycle or exporting packaging waste for recovery overseas.
details.licence_overview:
If you recover, recycle or export packaging waste for recovery overseas, you can apply to your environmental regulator for accreditation.

Your environmental regulator is the:

  • Environment Agency in England and Wales
  • Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) in Scotland

Recovering waste involves burning it as a fuel or using it to create energy in some other way. Recycling waste means creating new products from materials which have been thrown away.

Accreditation is a voluntary process but will allow your business to receive payments from registered producers for issuing electronic packaging waste recovery notes (ePRNs) and electronic packaging waste export recovery notes (ePERNs).

How to apply

You can apply for accreditation online using the National Packaging Waste Database (NPWD).

Accreditations last for a maximum of one year and run from January to December. You must apply by 30 September if you want your accreditation to start from 1 January of the following year.

Before granting accreditation, an environmental officer may contact you to arrange a site visit.

Your regulator will notify you whether your application was successful within 12 weeks of submission.

Once you are accredited you can use the NPWD to:

  • record the waste packaging you have received for reprocessing or export
  • fill in your three-monthly returns for waste packaging you have reprocessed or exported
  • issue ePRNs and/or ePERNs

If you are reprocessing or exporting iron, steel or aluminium packaging, you must check whether your supplier is accredited and, if so, whether they have issued ePRNs on the loads they are sending to you - ie to prevent issuing a second ePRN for the same metal waste packaging.

When renewing your accreditation, you should revise your business plan to reflect your strategy for the new accreditation period.

If you fail to comply with any accreditation conditions (eg supplying records and reports) your accreditation may be suspended or cancelled.
